When it comes to dying, few of us want to think about it until we have to. But, as Debbie Purdy's unsuccessful challenge to the law on assisted suicide shows, there is a contradiction at the heart of British law which causes a desperate dilemma for many thousands of people and their loved ones facing the reality of death.

If any of us were asked whether we would want to have options and dignity at the end of our lives, I am sure we would all agree that we would. Yet options and dignity can be in short supply at the very time it matters most.

Consider for a moment that someone very close to you has a terminal illness. Doctors have been clear about what will happen. They will gradually lose their faculties, their symptoms will worsen and their quality of life is likely to deteriorate. What are the options?

One: access to services. You'd want them to have access to the best possible care and treatment. However, at present the provision of good quality palliative care is patchy and varies enormously across health settings.

Two: control. It is crucial that dying people have control over their care and treatment, whether their last days and months are spent in a hospital, a care home, a hospice, or at home. This control extends from the "big" things such as refusing treatment, to the seemingly "small" but often equally important things such as having your favourite music to hand.

Three: the ultimate decision. If somebody feels their suffering has become unbearable they should have the option to choose when they die, within strict safeguards.

And here is the tragic dilemma. Medically assisted dying is illegal in the UK. So either the doctor does it surreptitiously, as around 900 a year already do, or we go to a foreign country. Both options leave people vulnerable and open to prosecution, either medical professionals or individuals.

In Debbie Purdy's case, she wants the option to travel to Switzerland where assisted dying is legal. But because assisting suicide is illegal in the UK, her husband faces the prospect of up to 14 years in jail if he helps her. But helping her into a taxi, packing her bags and travelling with her to a foreign country, what constitutes assisting suicide?

Yet, despite 100 Britons having gone to Dignitas, no one has ever been prosecuted. So, although the law knows assisting suicide is illegal, where compassion and choice comes in, there is a tacit acceptance that the law doesn't fully apply.

Debbie doesn't want to go to Dignitas with even the slightest possibility that her husband will face jail. Debbie enjoys life. But she may decide to die early. In her case, because the law is unclear, her life may end before it has to which is preposterous. She and her husband deserve clarity.

As Debbie has now lost her case, the confused status quo will remain. People will continue to help their loved ones to go abroad to die. Doctors will continue to exercise compassion to gently send their patients to sleep. Some loved ones will discuss the awful prospect of helping their partner to die at home. All will be wrong in the eyes of the law. All will be open to prosecution.

Logic, clarity and honesty say that this is wrong. It is time for an open debate about this issue. If the law is unclear on assisting suicide on grounds of compassion then it must change. We know that Debbie will exhaust all the legal options available to her. However, it has been made clear both in the judgment handed down and by the director of public prosecutions that this is now an issue for parliament.

We believe that the public pressure behind this issue and the confusion that exists in the interpretation of the law on assisted suicide means that this is where the debate must go from here. Some on the extreme fringes of this argument say that, if the law changes, people will choose to end their lives early so as not to be a burden on their relatives. If someone feels this way, they can do this now.

Opponents say that it would have allowed Harold Shipman to get away with his terrible crimes. Wrong. Evidence from countries where assisted dying is legal demonstrate it actually provides better security for patients than where it is banned. Regulating this area would lead to checks and cross checks, the requirement for discussion and consent, the involvement of more health professionals, counsellors and agencies. People such as Shipman would not be able to operate alone. Both patients and doctors would be safer.

A change in the law would protect the vulnerable. It would clarify the position for the medical profession. It would end so-called mercy killings. At a stroke, it would sweep away those tragic, awful dilemmas felt by people like Debbie Purdy and her husband every day of every week. It is one option among others, including universally available high-quality palliative care, to which we should have a right.

Nobody wants to be forced to confront their death but when we do, we should have the right to options and clarity. We should all have access to high quality palliative care wherever we live. We should all have the option to die surrounded by our relatives at home. And we should also know that loved ones and doctors are not open to prosecution for complying with our wishes.

And, yes, we should have the option to go when we choose, competent and able to function with dignity as a human being.

The jury's finding on Alaskan senator Ted Stevens brings the conviction rate among US senators to 5%, which, if all the perps were incarcerated, would be even higher than the imprisonment rate for the hoi polloi in the country they have been ruling. However, Stevens is unlikely to go down for his sins. And there should be a lot more than five senators in the penalty box.
The sins for which the jury convicted Stevens seem very minor in the scale of things. Accepting a quarter of a million dollars worth of home improvements from an oil contractor in a fit of absentmindedness actually pales in comparison with his real depredations whose nature only differed in degree from his colleagues in the Congress.

It is very difficult for Europeans to understand why it is perfectly fine to do hugely expensive political favours, of the kind that festooned the $700bn bail-out bill, in return for contributions to political campaigns, but it is beyond the pale to accept a few personal sweeteners to enhance home comforts. They both smack of bribery and corruption.
When Clinton took $500,000 from the CEO of Chiquita Brands and within weeks launched a hugely expensive trade war with Europe over Caribbean bananas, British negotiators were bemused when their American counterparts disclaimed any connection between the two events.

It was self-evident what had happened even if there had not been a recidivist Clintonian pattern – like kissing up to Scientology in return for Hollywood contributions, or selling policy on Cuba in return for $275,000 from the Cuban exiles in Miami.
Stevens is as popular in Alaska as only someone could be who has doubled federal spending in his state to $10bn a year. Hell, he was even popular with Sarah Palin despite her current desire to keep a leper's leap away from him.

Relatively small contributions to campaigns unleash astronomic amounts of dollars that do not really count because the federal treasury is seen as a bottomless pit of other people's money – except when someone suggests it should go to children's health care, poverty alleviation, education or some other such morally debilitating purpose.

It is almost a truism that if a state's representatives preach low taxes and fiscal restraint, then they will be dipping the till regularly filled by the taxpayers of the states whose representatives they scorn as tax and spenders. Hardy self-reliant, Alaska, the steady top of the league for per capita federal spending, and with little or no local taxation except on the oil industry, depends on the kindness of strangers below the Canadian border to a degree that almost makes it an honorary constituent of the revived and until recently triumphant confederacy. One third of all jobs and personal spending in Alaska come care of the taxpayers and tax-and-spend voters down below.

In the Alaskan capital of Juneau earlier this year, my hosts proudly showed me the local hotel where federal wiretaps nailed local politicians for corruption – and it was that probe that caught Stevens in a collateral conviction. Interestingly, there have even been academic studies showing that "larger federal transfers are associated with higher rates of conviction for abuse of public office, supporting the theory that soft-budget constraints created by federal transfers are potentially problematic".

In other words, where there is free money, politicians will take it, and between oil and federal largesse, Alaska is full of it.
In the 18th century, British politics was about gaining control of the treasury and looting it to pay off your supporters. American politics, from the same roots, skipped the reforms, and is in fact, as Tony Blair demonstrated, re-importing the old model. It would be a stretch to wear badges proclaiming "Stevens is innocent", but one cannot help thinking that his felonies are mere peccadilloes in the broader, thoroughly corrupt scheme of things. How many schools, how much children's health insurance could Stevens's $300m million "Bridge to Nowhere" (that Palin supported before she didn't) have paid for?
One can only hope that Obama has the integrity to welsh on all or some of the obligations his many corporate donors may feel were attached to their cheques.

The decade and a half of New Labour in the UK and the New Democrats in the States, of Blair and Clinton, finally made explicit the exhaustion and dilution of social democracy and progressive liberalism. Rather than lament this fact, Blair and Clinton, danced with glee on the grave of the conventional shibboleths of the centre-left.

Now that New Labour and the New Democrats have passed into history, some think we can get back to our old ways and re-start the great moving-left story.

Whether sadly or not, we can't just go back to where we thought we once were before we were so rudely interrupted by Blair and company. New Labour was only possible because of a long-term crisis in Labour, its politics and appeal.

Labour used to define and think of itself via a number of galvanising and mobilising stories and myths. These allowed activists and members, and even in the past, government ministers, to believe that they were part of a bigger, transformative project, and one which made all the compromises worthwhile.

First, there was the story of the Labour movement, a progressive coalition for change, which brought together trade unions comprising working people who supported a more equal society. Second, was the vague idea of socialism, never clearly defined, so as not to alienate the more practical trade union wing, but nevertheless, constantly cited and invoked.

Then there was the story of the state. Labour viewed the state as "neutral", influenced by Fabianism which valued the role of the expert and planner. The state could be an arbiter, shaper, leveller and liberator, redistributing from rich to poor, whether it be at the level of individuals, communities and regions.

Finally, there was the idea of Britain and a British story. From Wick to Cornwall, this story gave working people the hope and belief that Britain was a progressive story centred on lifting people out of poverty and dead-end jobs, and offering the prospect of greater knowledge and opportunity to the next generation.

These four pillars were cracking and falling apart long before New Labour appeared on the scene; New Labour merely stamped and humiliated them into the dirt. What comes next will be shaped and determined by the collapse of the four pillars of the house of Labour.

A number of avenues are possible from the debris. First is the Brown approach to try to keep the big tent viable as long as possible. Thus, Brown wants to breath new life into sentimental talk of the "Labour family", invoke a progressive consensus, see a pivotal role for an enlightened state, and go on about Britishness as the new glue holding it together.

Second, is the New Labour Stage Two project associated with Progress and others which amounts to the "new conservativism". This group – Milburn, Byers and Mandelson – cannot change the old record of going on about the concerns of business, labour market flexibility, and the need for Britain to remain competitive in the age of globalisation. Brown wants to keep this perspective in the tent pissing in, rather than outside, as seen in the recent appointment of Mandelson and his comments about postponing the introduction of parental rights to help business in these difficult times.

The third possibility starts from acknowledging the cul-de-sac New Labour has taken us into. Any new kind of progressive politics after Blair and Brown is going to have to address the terrain they left: the hollowing out of Labour and the dilution and demeaning of social democracy at the hands of neo-liberalism.

Any new progressivism has to think differently about the state and the nation from New or Old Labour. The command and control state of Herbert Morrison and his grandson, Peter Mandelson, is surely now completely discredited. And the old British story can no longer plausibly continue, in light of two decades of corporate power and a disastrous foreign policy fighting two losing wars. Brown and the Blairite last guard don't even recognise the problem in these terms.

We should look for a new political project which makes explicit the links between our economy, society and democracy, and charts a way out of our atrophied, deformed political system. What we need to do is look at how we democratise our politics, state and make the connections between this and how we think of the economy.

Can Labour contribute to this project, or are they part of the problem? Is such a project beyond the Westminster political classes, who with honourable exceptions have proven themselves craven and impotent in the face of the neo-liberal juggernaut?

A new political era is beginning as the old neo-liberal order falls apart. All across the world, from the US presidential elections to the UK, Europe, Latin America and elsewhere, people are looking for a way out of the debris, chaos and deceit of the neo-liberal era. It is going to be messy in Britain, given its near-total dominance of politics, business and the media, but the fightback has begun.

It would be a wonderful, positive outcome if Labour could find a voice and soul again which was not part of the orthodoxies and problems created these last two decades.

Britain is joining a growing international diplomatic effort to end the interminable conflict in eastern Congo with the foreign secretary, David Miliband, expected to fly to Goma tomorrow amid increasing questions about the effectiveness of the United Nations peacekeeping mission there.

Miliband is travelling with his French counterpart, Bernard Kouchner, to the beleaguered east Congolese town as well as Congo's capital, Kinshasa, and neighbouring Rwanda. They are following in the footsteps of the top US envoy for Africa, Jendayi Frazer, as the EU considers sending forces to the area and the UN appeals for more troops for what is already the largest peacekeeping force in the world.

But the visits come amid concern that UN peacekeepers in eastern Congo are effectively fighting a war that government forces are fleeing and in doing so are siding with extremist Hutus responsible for the genocide in neighbouring Rwanda.

Critics of the UN operation - and some of its own staff - say the mission is complicating efforts to reach a peace settlement because, instead of pressing the disarmament of all major rebel groups, the UN has effectively taken sides against the Tutsi rebel leader, Laurent Nkunda, on behalf of a government whose own forces are deeply implicated in human rights abuses and more interested in making money from gold smuggling than fighting. The government's army is also allied with exiled Rwandan Hutu rebels.

But UN officials in Congo privately say they have been left by the major powers to do an impossible job because of lack of international political will to confront the causes of more than a decade of conflict that has claimed about 5m lives, mostly from disease, and left more than one million as refugees.

As tens of thousands fled the latest upsurge in fighting this week, people vented their anger at the UN's inability or failure to fulfil its basic mandate of protecting civilian lives.

Residents of Goma stoned UN compounds in the town as Nkunda's forces marched toward the town and government forces fled. Refugees pelted UN convoys with rocks, critically injuring an Indian army officer.

In response, the UN secretary general, Ban Ki-moon said peacekeepers in Congo are "doing everything possible to protect civilians and fulfil their mandate in untenable circumstances". One UN official said untenable meant that peacekeepers were expected to fight when the government's own army will not.

Alan Doss, the UN envoy to Congo, said the peacekeepers have served with "really great distinction" but that there are not enough of them to fulfil the mandate of protecting the civilian population.

The UN has 17,000 troops in Congo. About one-third of them are in North Kivu, the most conflict-riven province, mostly from India.

But critics say that more troops are not the answer because the UN has been given a role it cannot fulfil and has become deeply compromised as a result.

Neil Campbell, a researcher for the International Crisis Group who recently visited Goma, said it was never feasible to expect the UN to protect civilians outside of a few urban areas given the vastness of eastern Congo and the array of armed groups preying on people.

"The UN has been projected as the body that's going to bring democracy and stabilisation to the north east of Congo which is completely unrealistic," he said.

"The problem is the UN has been forced in to fighting by the disintegration of the (government's) army. When I was in Goma, the sense of a lack of discipline and any kind of military cohesion within the armed forces is incredible. This is what you can see has happened in the last few days. It's really been the armed forces that have been running away from the rebels, so the UN has been forced into a role that it wasn't supposed to be taking."

After the failure of UN peacekeeping during the Rwandan genocide, the mission to Congo was given a strong mandate to use as much force as deemed necessary to protect civilians. But that has done little to prevent staggering human rights abuses.

Human Rights Watch has criticised the UN not only for failing to prevent systematic rape across eastern Congo, where it is effectively a weapon of war and terror, but also for remaining virtually silent about such crimes against humanity.

Instead, the UN has concentrated on trying to prevent the various rebel groups from taking over major towns. But in doing so it has been drawn in on one side of the conflict on the grounds that it was defending a democratic government in Kinshasa.

But that role was compromised because government forces were often responsible for their own human rights abuses, including murder and rape, and are heavily involved in making money from illegal mining operations.

Global Witness recently accused sections of the Congolese army of mining gold and tin in league with the Rwandan Hutu rebel group, the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Rwanda (FDLR), whose leaders are heavily implicated in the 1994 genocide.

Some UN peacekeepers have also been accused of involvement in the illegal mining trade and gold smuggling.

Congo's president, Laurent Kabila, has also been protecting the FDLR, which controls large parts of eastern Congo, because its forces have proven more willing to fight than his own troops and have gone into combat against Nkunda who has had the backing of Rwanda, at least in the past.

All that has left UN forces fighting with, and effectively protecting, not only the illegal mining trade but forces responsible for mass murder in neighbouring Rwanda.

UN officials also privately accuse the Congolese army of forcing peacekeepers into action by attacking Nkunda's men forces and then retreating, leaving the UN to defend positions.

Campbell says the scramble for control of lucrative mines remains a driving force behind the conflict.

"Everyone is gaining something from the North Kivu crisis, political or economic interests. There's active collaboration between the army and the FDLR. At the moment the army appears to be doing more of this business activities with the FDLR than actually functioning as the army itself," he said.

"Nkunda presents himself as being the protector of the Tutsis in North Kivu. He's nothing of the sort. He's not a freedom fighter, his primary goal is economic and political interests. He's supported by Tutsi businessmen in Goma that are using him for their ends. The areas he controls contain mining concessions they receive funds from."

"At this stage it's not additional troops that's going to protect civilians. It's international political pressure on Rwanda and Kinshasa to pull Nkunda and the FDLR back and to get the peace agreements underway," he said.

There is a lot of talk about talk with the Taliban in the air. From Washington, London, Peshawar, Kabul, Islamabad and Mecca over the past three weeks we have had news reports on "contacts" between Taliban, Afghan, Pakistani and US representatives about a negotiated solution for the fighting in Afghanistan.

Most sources agree that these amount to little more than "putting out feelers", "testing the water", and "making contacts". In diplomatic-speak this activity appears have the urgency for which the Spanish concept of mañana would be an exaggeration.

For what are the talks aimed at, what kind of Afghanistan do they hope to achieve and in what time-frame? And where's the plan, the strategy, to get this?

This appears to have been the message at a forum convened at the Army and Navy Club close to the White House two weeks ago – details of which have just emerged this morning in the New York Times. Delegates included Kai Eide, the UN Special representative in Kabul, and the former US commander in Afghanistan, General Karl Eikenberry. For two days they briefed security advisers to Barak Obama and John McCain.

Their message was blunt: whoever is sworn in as the next president on January 20 next must have a clear plan for Afghanistan will be too late as security through key parts of the country continues to "spiral down".

The new American Central Command chief, General David Petraeus, has proposed a surge of a further 20,000 American troops, hoping that will fix security in Afghanistan as he says his surge of 35,000 extra forces did in Iraq last year.

But Afghanistan is a whole different tactical ball game from Iraq, from terrain to enemy strengths and tactics and the abilities of the host government forces. The famous Petraeus surge trick may not work twice.

On Tuesday this week the Foreign Secretary David Miliband and the new Defence Secretary John Hutton, flanked by advisers, discussed Iraq and Afghanistan before the combined defence and foreign affairs committees of the House of Commons for some two and a half hours.

The testimony was precise and detailed, but in the end amounted to little more than wondering out loud.

They speculated about the outcomes of the three elections next year in both countries. They wondered what the shape of future governance in Kabul might be. They pondered how to tackle the narco-crime-terrorist economy. There were dark mutterings about Pakistan. This included a wonderful bit of wishful thinking about "getting the Pakistan army to concentrate on the battle for Afghanistan, and not their preoccupation with India". One wonders what particular planet the policy advisers at the FCO and MoD were on when they came up with that line.

The day after, Wednesday, the MoD announced an emergency £700m package to buy a range of 700 new vehicles designed to resist the new generation of mines and remotely triggered bombs being used by the Taliban. These include mine removers, armoured diggers, recce vehicles, personnel and ammunition carriers. The Americans are placing a similar order with Oshkosh and Force Protection for mine-resistant vehicles.

The sense of strategy for both Iraq and Afghanistan is in danger of being lost in an ocean of tactical ideas and initiatives. To say we are going to stick it out, and hope to grind down the Taliban over the next 10 years is not a realistic strategic goal. After all, look at what has been achieved by the internationals in Afghanistan in the seven years since November 2001. (While there have been some gains socially, in health and education, security and the narco-economy must be put in the loss columns of the ledger).

This week Henry Kissinger offered some pithy thoughts about the Vietnam saga, which should provide food for thought for the new US president. Critiquing the reflections of McGeorge Bundy, Kennedy's National Security Adviser, prepared by his researcher, and now critic, Gordon M Goldstein, Kissinger gave these thoughts: "The purpose of war is victory. Stalemate is ... not a desirable strategic objective. Victory needs to be defined as an outcome achievable in a timeframe sustainable by American public opinion."

All very well to have such 20-20 hindsight now, you may argue. However, Kissinger's warning about time in such conflicts is – pardon the pun – timely for what is now happening in Iraq and Afghanistan. Time is running out for the US and its allies in both countries – as the status of forces wrangle is proving in Iraq. You cannot talk about "generational wars" and "open-ended commitments" to seeing it through. You cannot say your forces can be squatters in these lands, when international law and diplomacy, and lore of the insurgents, does not recognise international squatters' rights.

Over the past year, a select group of US and European diplomats has become much more familiar with the protagonists in the drama playing out in North Kivu. After long talks in January and a series of short visits since, they know the leading players in this drama: the Congolese government and army, the UN and Laurent Nkunda's inner circle. They've heard the views of a smattering of North Kivu's humanitarians, politicians, businessmen, civil society types and militia leaders.

They cooked up a peace plan that elevated the profile of some obscure armed groups (and even a couple of semi-fictitious ones for luck). They talked it up, then watched it fall apart as the signatories broke all the rules. The Congolese army and the UN thought they were containing the rebels, now the army has fled and the rebels are pinning down the UN. Now they're wondering how to get all these people talking and behaving again.

In the diplomats' world, diplomats are centre stage. But diplomats are of marginal significance to the war-weary and increasingly frustrated local population, because they only seem concerned with the guys with the guns, and their schemes have yet to make a lasting difference.

This is fair, but not completely true: if Goma is not in rebel hands today, and North Kivu not swarming with Rwandan soldiers, it is partially due to heavy US restraining pressure on Kigali. They are right not to give up, and further talks are inevitable, so what should they do to put things on an even keel?

First, they should answer UN requests for more well-equipped troops (preferably special forces) capable of securing the territory surrounding Goma by force if necessary, and of helping to police the town itself. The EU may even mobilise a battle group to shore up the peacekeepers in the short-term (Britain's position on this could be decisive).

Second, to bring a minimum of security, equal attention needs to be paid to the risks posed by the utterly demoralised Congolese troops. They're incapable of taking on the rebels, so they too need to be regrouped and brought under control under new leadership as an urgent damage limitation objective. If they are allowed to run amok or even switch sides, all bets are off.

Third, maximum support and much greater prominence needs to be given to efforts to provide humanitarian assistance to the huge numbers of displaced people. Contrary to rumours, agencies like the Red Cross and MSF are still hard at work out there, and others are standing by.

Fourth, they need to keep or increase the pressure on Rwanda, while reverting to a meaningful plan to deal with the problem of the Rwandan Hutu genocidaires still lingering in Congo, thus taking away their pretext for interference and Laurent Nkunda's raison d'etre. But they must be ready to face the real prospect of a new political grouping emerging from the rebellion that will have no democratic legitimacy in Congo, but may yet offer a viable alternative to war.

These are merely crisis management measures that might stabilise the situation. Unless sufficient determination can be mustered to follow them up with more inclusive dialogue to address deeper problems including citizenship, management of natural resources, government legitimacy and return of refugees, violent instability will continue to plague eastern Congo and unsettle the entire region.

Entertainment Rights, the media group that owns children's favourites such as Postman Pat and Rupert Bear, faces huge debts after wiping £83m off the value of some of its characters, and has also admitted it may breach its banking covenants in the next few weeks.

The company, which has seen its share price plummet after a series of profit warnings, has taken the red pen most savagely to Basil Brush. It has written down the vast majority of the value of the puppet fox, one of the company's first properties, as an admission that he is unlikely to ever make millions by breaking into new markets, such as the US, or become a major merchandising hit.

Basil Brush's value has come down by £15m, while Entertainment Rights has slashed a further £42m off the value of business units that look after a raft of characters and brands including Transformers, He-Man, Roger Ramjet, Where's Wally and VeggieTales.

The reduction in the value of these assets, many of which were acquired during the company's spending spree two years ago, is also an admission that the current dismal economic climate is likely to affect sales of merchandise, such as DVDs.

Entertainment Rights added that it is locked in crucial negotiations with its main lender - Bank of Scotland - in an effort to renegotiate its overdraft. It was forced to ask the bank to temporarily waive the conditions attached to the loan and provide an emergency £1m lifeline after breaching its banking covenants in August.

It already owes £125m after a spate of acquisitions and its poor performance - that lead the firm to warn on profits for the second time in as many months on Friday - means the firm is likely to break its banking covenants again in November.

To try and save Entertainment Rights' precious cash, chief executive Nick Phillips has already identified £5m of cost savings and wants to save even more. He also plans to slash the company's spending budget from £17m last year to just £6m, and he focuses on some of the businesses' key brands.

As a result of this new focus Phillips, the former UK boss of music group Warner who took over the reins in March after the firm's founder and chief executive Michael Heap was ousted, said the company may look to sell some of its characters.

"We are not planning to push any particular cat or fox out of the door," he said, alluding to the company's roster of furry characters. "But we are selective acquirers and disposers of assets and certainly an announcement like this will generate interest."

Entertainment Rights amassed much of its debts two years ago when it went on a spending spree that included buying America's Classic Media for £107m. That deal brought Lassie and The Lone Ranger into the company's portfolio and made it the world's biggest independent owner of children's brands.

However, the company failed to fully integrate these businesses and costs ran out of control. It then suffered problems with a DVD distributor, which hit profits.

The chairman, Rod Bransgrove, admitted that the board's detailed review of the business, which has been going on for almost a year, unearthed "a number of issues", which "have conspired to present a worse picture than had previously been envisaged".

Bransgrove said the company should be back on a more stable footing by the end of its current financial year and "I intend to stand down as chairman at that point to allow others to drive the future success of the business".

But shares in the company, which was involved in talks about a possible takeover in the Spring, lost more than a third of their value, dropping to just 1.25p. At that level the business is worth just £9m. Two years ago Entertainment Rights was worth well over £250m.

The company is currently changing its year-end and as a result its half-year figures cover the eight month period to the end of August. As a result of the writedown, the company made a loss for that period of £105m compared with a £7.3m profit in the previous year.

The company is still trying to finalise an American broadcast contract and license a number of non-core publishing rights but warned on Friday that these deals may not materialise this year. As a result the company warned its profits before financial charges could be £10m lower than expected this year.

One rare bright spot for the business, which also announced the appointment of a new finance director, Edward Knighton, on Friday, is the forthcoming film of The Lone Ranger.

Producer Jerry Bruckheimer has lined up Johnny Depp to play the masked cowboy's sidekick Tonto and Entertainment Rights hopes that the film will boost sales of its Lone Ranger merchandise.

The company is already marking this year's 75th anniversary of the character with the release of a collector's edition DVD and plans range of Lone Ranger merchandise later this year.

There was a coup this year at the Viennale (Vienna's film festival), where discriminate and knowledgeable film-goers and film-makers meet. There were multiple screenings of the world premiere of a film made especially for and shown exclusively at the Viennale by one of the world's greatest directors. The fact that it ran for 63 seconds makes it no less of a coup for Hans Hurch, the festival's artistic director, whose radical taste is manifest in the varied selection of films.

When Hurch suggested to friends that he was determined to get JLG (most passionate cinephiles need only to see these initials to recognise whose they are) to make the publicity trailer for the festival – most of them scoffed. But Hurch, who had already got the likes of Stan Brakhage, Jonas Mekas, Leos Carax and Agnès Varda to make these one-minute films, persevered undaunted. The reason for the scoffing was because Jean-Luc Godard was so notoriously reclusive and so often refused invitations to appear at festivals or retropectives of his films, that many suitors have given up asking him. He has also, on occasions, promised to appear at events and not turned up at the last minute. There was the celebrated affair when he abandoned contributing to what was to be an exhibition dedicated to his work at the Beaubourg museum in Paris, leaving a dreadful mess.

So it was a real achievement when Hurch heard back from JLG by fax (he doesn't use emails) that he would be willing to make a trailer. Friends remained sceptical. Not Hurch. He knew that the 78-year-old Godard would deliver as promised because of Hurch's friendship with Jean-Marie Straub, whom Godard admires above all his contemporaries. And thus did Godard create the trailer in six days, and on the seventh day returned to his semi-retirement at his home on Lake Geneva in Switzerland.

Godard brazenly opens his mini-miracle, entitled Une Catastrophe, his first work since Notre Musique in 2004, with an extract from perhaps the most famous sequence in cinema history, the Odessa Steps section from Sergei Eisenstein's The Battleship Potemkin (1925). We see the populace running down the steps, and the mother carrying her child in the opposite direction (a perfect demonstration of Eisenstein's formula of thesis and antithesis creating synthesis). But Godard, a keen sports fan, characteristically creates an incongruous stratum with an accompanying soundtrack of the grunts of tennis players delivering a first service, and the sound of balls upon rackets. Then a colourised stop-motion sequence of a dead man and the title: C'est La Premiere.

A soldier stands with a machine gun at the ready before army tanks roll through a forest and planes start dropping red circular bombs. This is contrasted with a love scene, again in stop-motion, from the collective film People on Sunday (1930), the debut movie of three Austrian-born directors Edgar G. Ulmer, Fred Zinnemann and Billy Wilder, with a sonorous reading of a Low German 18th-century poem on the soundtrack. The film ends with the title De L'Amour and the beginning of Robert Schumann's piano cycle Scenes from Childhood.

Une Catastrophe is an autonomous piece, a cinematographic poem about violence and love, conceived in the style of Godard's Histoire(s) Du Cinéma with a combination of images, sounds, language and music. All in 63 seconds!

This was an apt prelude to the many films in the festival which do not conform to the tired narrative conventions of mainstream cinema. For example, Handl Klaus's intriguingly subtle March (März), set in a small Tyrolean town, scrutinises the families of three young men who committed an apparently motiveless suicide, but explains nothing on the smooth surface, merely suggesting the turmoil beneath. These people, who lead empty, ordinary lives, could be the very ones who voted for the far right in the recent election.

Three years ago, the young Catalonian Albert Serra's Honour of the Knights, which followed a journey of Don Quixote and Sancho Panza, was shown at the Viennale and won the International Critic's award. This year he returned with Birdsong (El Cant Dels Ocells), already shown at Cannes, another journey, this time of the three kings to pay homage to the baby Jesus.

The film, constructed of extremely long takes, the visual equivalent of the adagios from an Anton Bruckner symphony (so singular is the film that it is easier to find comparisons outside cinema), follows the Magi as they trudge across the desert. The journey, which manages to be both absurdist and religious, takes place in the heat of summer, unlike TS Eliot's "a cold coming we had of it" but, like the poem, the trio is aware that "this Birth was/ Hard and bitter agony for us, like Death, our death." There are some distant echoes of other films, the most direct homage being to Pasolini's The Gospel According to St Matthew (a reference for most auteurs tackling the subject) and the same director's The Canterbury Tales.

Except for one brief, moving sequence – as the three kings prostrate themselves at the tiny feet of Jesus the Catalan melody of the title plays – all sound is diegetic. Birdsong was accompanied by a revealing documentary, called Waiting for Sancho, on aspects of the making of the film, by the critic Mark Peranson, who plays a mournful Joseph.

These were among the highlights in a rich and off-the-beaten-track programme which included a homage to the tragic Austrian actress Nora Gregor, best known as the Marquise de la Chesnaye in Jean Renoir's The Rules of the Game, who committed suicide in 1949; the extraordinary left-wing documentaries of John Gianvito; a concert given by Ingrid Caven, Rainer Fassbinder's wife from 1970 to 1972; and a tribute to Bob Dylan in the movies. One film, where he can be heard singing When He Returns, is the satiric Grandeur and Decadence d'un Petit Commerce de Cinema, made for French television in 1986 by none other than JLG.

Two weeks ago, toymaking giant Smart Union was churning out goods for children across the United States and Europe. Now it is in liquidation and 7,000 former employees are in shock.

"One day we went to work as usual, the next it was all closed," said Wei Sunying, gazing through the barred gate of the factory in Dongguan in southern China where she spent eight years painting plastic components in a fume-filled room.

"Thousands of us are looking for jobs now. We walk around every day till our feet ache but we can't find anything."

Few in the west have heard of Dongguan, but the chances are that your shoes, your TV or your children's toys originated here. Exports have built a city of up to 14 million inhabitants — twice the population of Greater London — almost all migrant workers from the countryside. Its economy has grown 15% annually in recent years.

Now the global financial and economic crisis is proving the final straw for exporters already punished by rising costs and a stronger currency.

In the last year, chill winds have blown through the baking Pearl River Delta. Sixty-seven thousand small and medium-sized businesses in China collapsed in the first half of 2008, many in these manufacturing heartlands, says the national economic planning body. Toy firms have been particularly badly hit, thanks to safety scares and product recalls. Textile firms, with wafer-thin margins, are also reeling.

Next came tighter credit for many foreign-owned firms, such as Hong Kong's Smart Union. And then, in the last two months, a sharp drop in US and European demand as consumers reined in spending.

A local trade association predicts that by the end of January, Dongguan and its neighbours Shenzhen and Guangzhou will lose 9,000 of their 45,000 factories.

"Many factories are looking at completely empty order books," warned Stephen Green, head of China research at Standard Chartered, who believes the export sector will be stagnant and could even shrink next year.

Green predicts that China will grow 7.9% next year — well below the double-digit figures enjoyed over the last half decade — while others suggest it could fall closer to 7%.

That sounds enviable to western countries facing recession. But with the working age population still growing, China needs at least 8% growth to maintain the current employment rate. And the fall-out will be highly concentrated in provinces such as Guangdong.

"The social impact of this is going to be huge. The problems are getting bigger and bigger," said Wooyeal Paik, who is researching Dongguan's industry and migrant workforce at the University of California at Los Angeles.

"Impromptu protests by disgruntled workers left jobless and without pay are becoming more common; they have resorted to petitioning local officials for backpay because they have few other ways to remonstrate and be compensated.

"They will complain more and they will go to local government offices more... You will see demonstrations and picketing. And probably there's a risk of violence against bosses — especially foreigners."

Dongguan's government stepped in to reimburse the Smart Union workers to the tune of 24,000 yuan (£2.2m) after thousands gathered at the factory gates and outside local authority offices.

But two months' back pay — 1200 yuan for most — will not last long. There is no redundancy package and a lawsuit by workers appears to have limited prospects of success.

Wei, from Guizhou, is one of many struggling to find new work. Even if she could read the job adverts, most ask for recruits under 35; she is just over 40.

"I came here as a migrant worker because my children need money for schooling," she said.

"Now I can't support my children. I don't even have enough money to get back home and it's expensive to stay here."

Even job offers aren't always what they seem, said 26-year-old Fang Jianlin, whose friends were recently conned.

"Recruiters told them the conditions and the salaries were very good, but on the way to the place they were asked for money. They got robbed; some were even beaten," he said.

Smart Union was such a popular employer that Fang paid a hefty "introduction fee" to win his job there. At worst, he and his wife would earn around 600 yuan a month; at the busiest times, when production ran until 2am, they could take home 2,100 yuan each.

But he and his wife will return to his village in Sichuan in a few days, where his parents are rearing their children, unless new work turns up. They are not sure how they will support the family, but cannot afford the 50 yuan a day in rent, food and transport to stay here.

It's a sobering end to the dream which lures millions of workers to Dongguan each year, where they struggle and study their way towards the promise of a regular income; perhaps even a place in the burgeoning middle classes. At the city's night schools, thousands of workers end their long days with classes on everything from car maintenance to law.

Bob Li is one of the area's success stories. He arrived in 1995 as a casual labourer. "Everyone in my hometown had heard Guangdong was covered in gold," he said.

Now he manages a factory for Richall, which supplies durable bags to companies such as Walmart, Carlsberg and Disney. Twenty-five thousand totes for Tesco are stacked up awaiting delivery.

But he is unnerved by the economic downturn.

"These days it is getting more and more difficult for factories like us," he said, citing the cost of wages and materials.

"The exchange rate is already a huge issue here; people are losing interest. The price of our materials has risen because they're made from oil... Taken together, costs have risen by 30%-40%."

To some extent, Dongguan has become a victim of its own success. The rising prosperity of the region has created inflationary pressures. Workers want higher wages; new labour laws are designed to wipe out sweatshops but bring higher costs, which squeeze many companies.

Manufacturers have already fled inland to cheaper provinces, in many cases encouraged by Guangdong authorities, who hoped to move the province up the value chain — condensing 200 years of western industrial history into fewer than 15.

"We have a policy to empty the cage for the new birds," Guangdong's vice-governor, Wan Qingliang, told reporters this month.

"The ultimate target is to build the Pearl River Delta into the core region of modern manufacturing."

Others are unsure of the wisdom of the policy in the face of a worldwide downturn.

"Places like Guangdong miscalculated the development of the economy. They actually tried to push those labour intensive and small and medium sized enterprises out of the [established industrial] area because they wanted hi-tech industries there. But when something bad happens, like the economic downturn, what are they going to do?" said Paik.

He acknowledges that numerous East Asian economies, such as Japan, have moved up the value chain in just the same way; and that the Chinese government deserves to be confident, given its economic record.

"But they haven't experienced a serious economic downturn except right after 1989 and have been overconfident in their policy of the quick transformation of industrial structure toward hi-tech in Guangdong," he cautioned.

The risk is that officials push the city off the economic ladder rather than up it. Whether new subsidies, export tax rebates and other support for small businesses can save them remains to be seen.

Yet China's rising living standards in the 30 years since economic reforms were launched has left most people optimistic about its long-term prospects. Migrant workers returning home think they may come back in a few years. A security guard at the shuttered Smart Union plant is plotting out his course to university.

"If we compare the situation to when I first arrived, I have already found my pot of gold," said Li, the factory manager.

"But I can still see it's just the beginning."
