The BBC attempted last night to draw the poison from another calamitous week by taking the unprecedented step of banning its highest paid star for three months, and accepting the resignation of one of its most senior and best-loved executives.

The corporation suspended Jonathan Ross for 12 weeks without pay, calling his behaviour "utterly unacceptable", a move which effectively fines him £1.3m.

Mark Thompson, the director general, hopes the sanction will end the crisis, but some inside the BBC were lamenting the fact it was Radio 2's controller Lesley Douglas who was forced to carry the can for a lewd prank phone call by Ross and Russell Brand, who quit on Wednesday.

After a day which followed the script of other recent TV scandals, with camera crews swarming outside Thompson's Oxfordshire home and 24-hour news channels on standby outside the BBC Trust's headquarters in central London, there was a dramatic denouement.

Thompson and Sir Michael Lyons, the BBC Trust's chairman, announced that Douglas had resigned and Ross was suspended from all radio and TV shows until January.

The episode is the latest in a series of controversies to engulf the BBC over the past 18 months, including the scandal over misleadingly edited footage of the Queen, divisive internal rows over job cuts, and rigged charity phone-ins. After each, Thompson has promised new controls and to "learn the lessons", but some BBC insiders believe he is running out of road.

The latest scandal was sparked by a Radio 2 show on October 18 in which Ross and Brand left a series of lewd messages on the answering machine of the actor Andrew Sachs, 78. The show subsequently led to 37,500 complaints to the BBC.

"There are some absolute limits and this programme went over those limits. No one is above the law," said Thompson, who said he had only known about the scandal for the last three days, a revelation that will lead to further questions about how his colleagues dealt with the crisis in his absence.

Thompson, under pressure from inside and outside the BBC, gave the order to suspend Ross and Brand, before returning from his holiday in Sicily on Wednesday night after discussing the scale of the escalating crisis with Lyons.

Ross, whose £18m, three-year contract had become a lightning rod for critics of the BBC, was said to have accepted the sanction without complaint.

"I believe that he fully understands the seriousness of what has happened," said Thompson. "I have made very clear to him the central importance of the clause in his contract about not bringing the BBC into disrepute. We agree that nothing like this must ever happen again and that tight discipline will be required for the future."

In what may come to be seen as a watershed moment in the BBC's relationship with its top talent, the trust said there should also be additional controls in cases where the production company is owned or managed by the performer.

In recent years, it has become common practice for big name stars, such as Ross, to agree deals allowing them to make their shows through their own production company. Others, such as Jeremy Clarkson, have signed complex deals with the BBC's commercial arm to benefit from worldwide exploitation of their programmes.

The trust, after reviewing an interim report from management, said it was dismayed that the BBC had "fallen way short of the public's overall expectations". It also ordered Radio 2 to broadcast an on-air apology to listeners.

The departure of Douglas recalled the exit of former BBC1 controller Peter Fincham last year following the row over a misleadingly edited clip of the Queen supposedly storming out of a photoshoot. BBC insiders are furious that none

of the lessons of that affair appear to have been learned. The BBC was keen to point out that it was Douglas who made the decision to resign. Thompson said that while she was aware of the offending programme, she had not heard it before it was aired. "Over the 23 years of my career at the BBC I have enjoyed a deep love and respect for both the audience and the BBC," she said in her resignation letter. "The events of the last two weeks happened on my watch. I believe it is right I take responsibility for what has happened."

The trust also said editorial controls in non-news programmes should be stronger, especially in "high risk" areas.

Many within the BBC and the wider industry will lament the departure of Douglas, who shied away from speaking publicly but had a close relationship with staff and attracted a string of big-name presenters including Ross, Brand, Chris Evans, and Jeremy Vine to Radio 2.

"Lesley Douglas has made an enormous contribution to British radio and we have still seen no evidence that she was responsible for the failings that led to the show being broadcast," said Don Foster, the Liberal Democrats' media spokesman, last night.

"This resignation seems to have more to do with satisfying the media feeding frenzy than in working out what went wrong and ensuring it doesn't happen again."

Tube passengers sitting near Jean Charles de Menezes yesterday told the inquest into his death that no warnings were shouted by armed police before they shot him seven times in the head.

Speaking for the first time in public, the commuters described the moment officers boarded the train at Stockwell station, south London, on July 22 2005. Rachel Wilson, who was with her boyfriend, Ralph Livock, said at first she had thought the men were "playing a game" with a friend until she looked down and saw her hands spattered with blood.

Livock said the couple had no idea whether the men on the train were police or terrorists.

The couple's account, and those of other passengers, contradicted evidence given by firearms officers who told the hearing that they shouted "armed police" at De Menezes before opening fire. One officer said De Menezes moved towards him aggressively and he feared that he would detonate a bomb at any moment .

Livock and Wilson recalled that the train stopped at Stockwell for longer than usual that morning.

All of a sudden they heard somebody shouting "he's here" outside the train, before several casually dressed men armed with guns boarded their carriage.

Livock said: "One of my initial thoughts was it was all a game and they were a group of lads who were just having a laugh - a very bad taste laugh but just having a game on the tube, because they were just dressed in jeans and T-shirts, but with firearms."

Nicholas Hilliard QC, counsel to the inquest, asked Livock: "Had you heard anything said about police?"

He replied: "No, certainly not.

"And I remember that specifically because one of the conversations that Rachel and I had afterwards was that we had no idea whether these were police, whether they were terrorists, whether they were somebody else. We just had no idea."

He added: "The thing that made me realise it wasn't a group of lads playing around or something else happening was when the first shot was fired."

His girlfriend told the inquest the officers said nothing to identify themselves.

Wilson said: "First I thought they were messing around. Then I thought they were terrorists and it was only when I left the carriage and somebody moved me gently out of the way that I figured they must be good guys. Apart from that, I just didn't know who they were."

One man levelled a pistol at De Menezes but said nothing to him, Livock told the inquest. The Brazilian did not appear frightened but looked as if he was "waiting for somebody to tell him what was going on", the commuter said.

At this point two police marksmen shot De Menezes seven times in the head at point-blank range, having mistaken him for Hussain Osman, one of the failed suicide bombers of the day before.

Another commuter, Wesley Merrill, recalled that several of the men with guns were wearing police caps, but he could not remember hearing any of them say anything to De Menezes.

After the shooting Livock and Wilson fled from the carriage, boarding a Victoria line train towards central London. They got off at Pimlico, where they asked a station attendant to contact the police for them. The hearing continues.

England's biggest programme to handle catastrophes from terrorist attacks to widespread flooding is in danger of going awry because of sloppy management and woeful financial management, Edward Leigh, chairman of the Commons public accounts committee, warns today.

The £330m programme, run by the Fire and Rescue Service, was set up two days after the 9/11 attack on New York's twin towers. It involved the ordering of hi-tech equipment such as powerful water pumps and decontamination suits, setting up a national control centre and specialist training for firefighters.

A report published today by the National Audit Office says the programme has been hampered by delays, financial uncertainty, weak management and poor financial controls. "Progress relied more on the enthusiasm, commitment and hard work of the project teams than coherent programme management," say the auditors.

The programme has had a number of successes. New equipment helped firefighters to put out the huge oil fire at Buncefield, near Hemel Hempstead in Hertfordshire, in 2005 more quickly and prevented an electricity power station from being flooded in last year's flooding in Gloucestershire.

However, the report warns that if the 2007 flooding had happened simultaneously in the West Country and Yorkshire, 76 high-volume pumps would have been needed - 26 more than the number in England and Wales. The Fire and Rescue Service also wasted millions of pounds on consultants, many charging more than £1,000 a day, against a budget of £500 a day.

The auditors say that much more planning is needed to cope with future emergencies, with clearer lines of responsibility for commanders. Some regions still do not have emergency plans and other regions do have not enough capacity to handle emergencies.

Leigh said: "It [the programme] has been sloppily managed, with poor procurement, poor implementation and woeful financial management. All of this contributed to a delay of up to five years and significant cost increases.

"Most worryingly, there are question marks over the ability to deal with future emergencies because there is confusion about local commanders' responsibilities, emergency plans leave a lot to be desired, and the department don't even know where capability gaps remain.

"This project is too important to be allowed to go awry. The consequences of [it] failing could be unthinkable."

Sadiq Khan, the fire minister at the Department for Communities and Local Government, said: "The NAO records that England's Fire and Rescue Service's capacity to respond to major emergencies has been much enhanced."

Peter Rose could be forgiven for having delusions of grandeur. He is about to open in the title role of Boris Godunov at English National Opera - tsardom beckons - and in January will play the Pope in Palestrina in Munich. But, happily, Rose is the antithesis of the operatic prima donna, and, were it not for the fact he is currently being carried everywhere on a portable throne, would have his feet firmly on the ground.

"Gin and tonic please," he jokes, as he is carried past by four weary-looking attendants. Rose is a big man, and being an imperial throne-carrier is no picnic. But they manage not to drop him, and the only accident at the rehearsal I attend befalls a woman in the chorus, who is struck a resounding blow on the head when a wooden icon topples off a shelf. Let's hope this is not an omen.

Otherwise, the portents for this new production are good: Tim Albery directs Mussorgsky's original seven-scene version, which has more narrative coherence than the longer version that emerged later; ENO's charismatic music director, Edward Gardner, is in the pit; and Rose is making his debut as Boris - a major role at last for a highly regarded bass who has built a strong reputation abroad while remaining strangely anonymous here.

Does the anonymity bother him, I ask in the first of several brief breaks from the rigours of rehearsal. Does he envy someone like Bryn Terfel, with his starry profile and money-spinning record deals? "I'm sure there is envy in the business," he says, "but I'm not competitive, at least I hope not in that way. I don't look at other singers and think, 'I've got to be having that sort of career.' I'm very happy with what's going on. I sing in some fantastic houses. I sing at the Met and in Vienna and Paris. I'm going to be making my Scala debut [as Ochs in Rosenkavalier in 2011]. I've got some nice places to be singing, so I don't think I've got anything to be envious about, and I quite like the anonymity. I don't really want to be recognised. It's lovely when people appreciate what you do, but I value my privacy."

Why has he tended to make his career abroad? "It's often the way that one has to go away and prove oneself there before the people at home take you seriously," he says. "Maybe it would have helped if I'd been called Rosovski or something more glamorous than boring, plain old Rose. But I'm now starting to do some big roles in this country that I've been doing abroad. Next year I'm doing Ochs at Covent Garden. I've sung there fairly regularly but in medium or supporting roles, and it's only now that they're starting to think about me for the major roles."

Rose calls himself an "accidental" singer. He grew up in Kent in a not especially musical family, sang in choirs at school and gradually got the bug - learning piano, conducting the local church choir, and even trying his hand at composing. He studied music at the University of East Anglia and planned to teach, but he carried on with singing lessons and gradually realised he really could sing.

"Initially, I thought I'd teach and sing local choral society stuff - that was the height of my ambition," he says. "I certainly didn't think I'd be an opera singer. I'd have been very happy doing the odd Messiah and Creation in village choral societies. But I could feel I was making progress - people would remark on it when I came home in the Christmas and Easter breaks - and I made such quick progress that I thought maybe I'm better than I thought I was. So in my second year at university, I thought, well, maybe I should give this singing lark a whirl."

His family were doubtful at first. "I remember my father saying, 'What do you mean, singing for a living?'" recalls Rose. "He was a policeman and thought I should be a lawyer or a doctor. He saw music as something to be enjoyed, not as a serious business. They've changed their mind now, but there was a resistance."

Rose went on to study at the Guildhall, then the National Opera Studio, and at 24 made his debut in a Glyndebourne touring production of Don Giovanni in Hong Kong, as an absurdly precocious Commendatore. Then, as is usually the case with basses, it was a matter of watching, learning and waiting - for the voice to mature and the jowls to grow into the parts. "You're just killing time, really," he says. "A lot of young basses and baritones do a number of what one might call spear-holding parts and supporting roles, and I did my fair share of those."

Now, at 47, Rose reckons it's his moment. "I think that's a good age for basses," he says. "My teacher, who died about five years ago in his 90s, used to say when I was in my 20s and 30s, 'Oh your voice won't even start to come into its own until you're in your 40s and 50s.' I wasn't sure whether I believed him or not, but I'm starting to feel that now I'm becoming a grown-up singer." Tenors may have all the fun and hit all the high notes, but their voices are usually shot by their mid-50s, when the jowly, growly basses are still in their prime.

Rose hopes to get the chance to sing Boris elsewhere, though learning it in Russian will be a huge undertaking - he said it took him eight months to learn the part in English for his ENO debut. Meanwhile, he will be taking Ochs - his signature role - around the world, and will also make his debut as Falstaff in Seattle in 2010.

One part he is unlikely to take on is Wotan, which he says lies a little too high for his voice, though he doesn't rule it out completely. "There are always people who are willing to seduce one with those marvellous parts," he says, "but I don't hanker after Wotan and I'm not sure it's me. Vocally I can probably do the Rheingold, but the other parts of the cycle are somewhat more stratospheric. I might be wrong, and maybe I'll come to a stage where I think actually I want to give that a try, and possibly Sachs [in Die Meistersinger], but at the moment, if we're talking Wagner, I'm happy doing Gurnemanz in Parsifal and Fasolt in the Ring and maybe Hunding."

Rose now has the luxury of being, to some extent, in control of his career, picking the parts he wants to sing. "I'm more selective about what I say yes to now. The fundamental thing at the beginning is, 'How am I going to pay my mortgage?' I'm not saying that's not the case now, but there's an element of, 'Well, I think I can probably say no to that, I'll have a break.' I have friends who have snow blindness when they open their diary, and if a job comes up they don't care what it is, they'll take it. It's that or opera Giro. Fortunately, I'm not in that position. I've got enough work over the next four or five years that, if I have a couple of gaps, I'm not frantic about it."

The bell sounds and it is back to rehearsal. This large, jolly, easygoing man immediately has to get back into character as the guilt-ridden, mentally broken Boris, the tsar who won the throne by engineering the death of the tsarevich, Dmitry, and is haunted by bloodied images of the dead boy. Rose, on his dais, instantly assumes the robes - a shiny green dressing gown grabbed from a wardrobe - of impotent power. No ham acting and old-fashioned gestures here, but an attempt to internalise Boris's breakdown. Who needs Rosovski when you've got Rose?

Mussorgsky's masterpiece

The story behind Boris Godunov

Modest Mussorgsky's work list is as muddled and incoherent as his own life was. A litany of musical might-have beens strewn with works left unfinished or even barely begun. Largely self-taught as a composer, Mussorgsky was essentially an amateur, yet he became a pivotal and profoundly original figure in mid-19th-century Russian music, while his influence on Debussy, Ravel and even Stravinsky ensures his place among the major precursors of modernism.

The core of Mussorgsky's achievement as a composer is to be found in his songs and operas, and in one opera above all. Boris Godunov, based like so many of the greatest Russian operas on a text by Pushkin, was his masterpiece. Yet despite its undisputed greatness, there is no such thing as a definitive version of this teeming, complex score, with its almost Shakespearean richness of character and incident, an unprecedented dramatic use of the chorus, speech-inflected vocal writing and rawboned orchestral textures.

Mussorgsky himself completed and orchestrated two distinct versions of the work. His first attempt, composed in 1868 and 1869 consists of just seven scenes, but its political and musical radicalism were too much for the Mariinsky Theatre in St Petersburg, which rejected it out of hand. Mussorgsky immediately set about revising the work, adding extra scenes including an entirely new act, as well as toning down some of its more obvious antitsarist sentiments. That version was performed with great success (though still with one scene censored for political reasons) in St Petersburg in 1874.

It was after Mussorgsky's death in 1881 at the age of just 42, that the problems began. In 1896 Rimsky-Korsakov reorchestrated and "improved" the score, believing that the original, crude and — as he saw it — uninspired scoring was part of the reason for the work's neglect, and this was the version in which Boris Godunov was presented around the world for the next 50 years. In 1940 Shostakovich, too, made his own orchestration, closer to the spirit of the original than Rimsky's. But it's only in the past quarter century that opera houses have started to go back to Mussorgsky's scores, sometimes making their own hybrids of the 1869 and 1874 versions. English National Opera is performing the original seven scenes that the Mariinsky rejected in 1869. It is Boris Godunov as Mussorgsky's unruly genius originally conceived it, warts and all.

Radio 2's controller, Lesley Douglas, has shown a sense of responsibility and dignity rare among the BBC's management in resigning over the Ross-Brand affair. It breaks with a disgraceful BBC tradition of passing the buck as far down the line as possible. And it shows that she, perhaps alone among the senior managers at the corporation, is ready to recognise the acute difficulties junior editorial staff face when they are given notional responsibility for wilful on-air talent.

It is not a new problem. Early in my broadcasting career I was assigned the job of producing a radio star. The editor told me confidentially that the great man was not at the top of his game. It was my task to radically improve the quality of what went out.

As a young, earnest producer, I took it seriously. My duty was clear, and it was to the audience. On day one I suggested how we might rewrite a slightly misleading script, and the star shouted at me for my temerity. On day two I recut a package and the star ordered me out of the editing suite in a rage. On day three I asked him to add a question to an interview. He slammed down the talkback button and stormed off to see the editor. On day four I was moved and a more amenable producer was brought in.

Too late I learned some essential lessons in management and tact. But the most important lesson was the power of the talent and the impotence of the producer. In theory I had editorial control and would certainly have been held to account if anything had been wrong. In practice he mattered and I didn't. He had the power while his producers were left with the responsibility.

That wasn't a truth the management was willing to address, but it is the issue that underpins the Ross-Brand affair. Everyone wants to know why the offending items were not edited out of the show. The 25-year-old producer was publicly castigated for his failure to hold the line on taste and decency, and it was widely speculated he would lose his job.

That is where Douglas stepped in. She let it be known that if her junior staff were to be sacked, she would rather resign. She had the grace to realise that frontline managers are the wrong targets. The real fault is a structural one for which senior management is responsible: a broadcasting culture in which editorial figures fear they'll get no backing higher up if they cross or challenge the super-talents they supposedly control.

Ferocious competition in the new media market has exacerbated the power gulf between editorial and talent. Someone like Ross knows he's bigger than a programme, or even a channel. His salary makes that clear. How easy is it for a minion on £25,000 or so, or an executive on £80,000, to say no to him?

The editorial teams who actually make decisions day to day are being landed with a nearly impossible task. They are urged to grab audiences, get out there, take the risks. Remote senior managers draw up general guidelines that don't cover the painful business of drawing lines every day. When Ross asked David Cameron if he'd had teenage sexual fantasies about Thatcher, there was no BBC censure.

This problem goes much further than a single controller. It's something for which the director general and his executives should take responsibility. They are the people driving a ratings-based, competition-obsessed model, which has them signing stars like Ross and then expecting people lower down to deal with any fallout. To them, Douglas is another pawn. In such crises, the top managers go to ground, too scared to put themselves in the firing line. They evade the fact that their systems devolve all the risk and none of the reward to people at the bottom. It's monumental managerial cowardice, and it's where our outrage should be directed.

If the words humanitarian catastrophe and eastern Congo have a familiar ring to them, it is because the fundamental causes of a conflict that has claimed five million lives and continues to kill 45,000 a month through starvation and disease remain unaddressed. And this despite the world's largest peacekeeping force, with the strongest mandate - to use lethal force if necessary to protect civilian lives. The 17,000-strong UN force, known as Monuc, has patently failed to do this. In most villages the militias represent the only law, the only protection from rape, crop-raiding and kidnap. The international community's attempts to restore order have lost all credibility.

The latest emergency comes with the advance of the rebel general Laurent Nkunda, who yesterday stopped his forces outside the eastern provincial capital, Goma, as government forces fled it. Nkunda claims the Congolese government has failed to protect his minority Tutsi tribe from the Rwandan Hutu militias, which escaped to the Congo after carrying out the genocide in Rwanda in 1994. He called for direct talks with the government and a revision of a $5bn deal which gives China access to the region's mineral riches in exchange for a railway and highway.

Goma in particular and the Congo in general have been here many times before. North and South Kivu, the crucible of conflict over land, minerals and ethnicity, are littered with broken ceasefires - almost one a year since peace was established in most other provinces in 2003. Attempts have been made to integrate militias into a national army. Those too have failed. The four constants in all this are the national army's failure to disarm the Rwandan Hutu militias with which they are closely linked, the routine use of rape, pillage and murder of civilians by all sides (including the rebel forces of Nkunda), the involvement of Rwanda and Uganda in Congo's affairs, and the general grab for natural resources.

There are rich pickings for the warriors. The tax levied by armed groups on charcoal alone amounts to $30m a year, and a UN investigation into the access, control and trade of coltan, diamonds, copper, cobalt and gold found that the exploitation of Congo's natural resources by foreign armies had been systematic. Nkunda says he is fighting to protect the hundreds of thousands of Tutsis in eastern Congo still threatened by the Hutu rebels. His forces are more disciplined than his adversaries. They took only the medicine they needed for their clinics as opposed to the widespread looting of the retreating Congolese army. But the longer this conflict continues, the more the rebel general's true motives come under scrutiny. It may be that he simply wants a larger slice of the mineral-rich cake.

Above all, eastern Congo's continuing misery represents an appalling failure of international will. The UN security council has demanded an end to the fighting, but continues to see Nkunda alone as the primary source of instability. France is talking about sending troops and the EU's aid chief, Louis Michel, yesterday met the president, Joseph Kabila, to see what could be done. But there is contempt for the UN among the population in Goma and little expectation among those fleeing their homes yesterday that it will stop the displacement, the disease and the rape.

The UN has the facts. A panel of experts has been investigating the government's armies' links with the Hutu militias and the extent to which Rwanda has backed Nkunda. They could use that evidence to pressurise the backers of both sides back to the negotiating table. The governments of both Rwanda and the Congo benefit from large amounts of foreign aid. That too could be used as leverage. What should not and cannot continue is the belittling spectacle of large numbers of UN peacekeepers unable or unwilling to do their job.
